Authors:
Maria Julia Nichea, Robert H. Proctor, Crystal E Probyn,
Sofia Palacios, Eugenia Cendoya, Michael Sulyok, Sofia Chulze, Adriana M
Torres, Maria Laura Ramirez
Title:
Fusarium chaquense sp. nov, a novel type A
trichothecene-producing species isolated from natural grasses (poaceae)
in a wetland ecosystem in Argentina
Keywords:
Fusarium, grasses, trichothecene type A, molecular
phylogeny
Abstract:
The Chaco wetland is formed by the floodplain of the
Parana and Paraguay rivers and is among the most biologically diverse
regions in Argentina. In collections of fungi from asymptomatic native
grasses (Poaceae) from a Ramsar site in the wetland, we identified
isolates of Fusarium that were morphologically similar to F. armeniacum,
but distinct from it by their production of microconidia. All the
isolates also had identical, or nearly identical, partial sequences of
TEF1 and RPB2, two genes used widely to distinguish Fusarium species
from one another. But the sequences were distinct from reference
sequences of F. armeniacum and related Fusarium species. Phylogenetic
analysis of 34 full-length gene sequences retrieved from whole genome
sequences resolved the Ramsar-isolates into an exclusive clade within
the F. sambucinum species complex. Based on results of the morphological
and phylogenetic analysis, we conclude that the wetland-grass isolates
are a distinct and novel species, herein described as Fusarium chaquense
sp. nov., that is most closely related to F. armeniacum. Analysis of
genome sequences also revealed that F. chaquense has genes required for
biosynthesis of trichothecene mycotoxins. In chemical analysis, F.
chaquense isolates produced type A trichothecenes T-2 toxin and HT-2
toxin, neosolaniol, diacetoxyscirpenol, and monoacetoxyscirpenol as well
as the mycotoxin beauvericin and the pigment aurofusarin. This research
represents the first study of Fusarium in a natural ecosystem in
Argentina.
